sa1:0.2: 1-4. Impermanent, Painful, Empty, and Not Self
sa1:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa1:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa1:2.2: “You should observe that form is [1] impermanent … [2] painful … [3] empty … [4] not self.
sa1:2.3: Such observation then is right view.
sa1:2.4: Correctly observing it gives rise to disillusionment.
sa1:2.5: Being disillusioned, delight and greed [for form] will end.
sa1:2.6: When delight and greed [for form] have ended, that’s said to be the mind’s liberation.
sa1:3.1: “Thus observe that feeling … perception … volition … consciousness is [1] impermanent … [2] painful … [3] empty … [4] not self.
sa1:3.2: Such observation then is right view.
sa1:3.3: Correctly observing it gives rise to disillusionment.
sa1:3.4: Being disillusioned, delight and greed [for consciousness] will end.
sa1:3.5: When delight and greed [for consciousness] have ended, that’s said to be the mind’s liberation.
sa1:4.1: “Thus, monks, someone wanting to realize the mind’s liberation for themselves then can realize it:
sa1:4.2: ‘My births have been ended, the religious practice has been established, and the task has been accomplished.
sa1:4.3: I myself know that I won’t be subject to a later existence.’”
sa1:5.1: When the monks heard what the Buddha taught, they rejoiced and approved.
